title: Title: Hurricane Katrina was a catalyst for change in New Orleans' public defender office
teaser: Teaser: Left to right: Ronald Marshall poses for a portrait outside the prison he was held in when Katrina hit. Orleans Parish District Attorney Jason Williams at his office in New Orleans. Meghan Garvey, the only full-time public defense attorney in New Orleans.Claire Harbage/NPRhide caption
body: Body: NationalHurricane Katrina was a catalyst for change in New Orleans' public defender officeHurricane Katrina exposed longstanding flaws in the New Orleans criminal justice system. In the 20 years since, there has been dramatic change in the public defender office.

title: Title: This Tuscan startup sold all its olive oil in the U.S. Then came Trump's tariffs
teaser: Teaser: Siblings Marie-Charlotte and Romain Piro in Tuscany, among some of the olive trees they harvest to create their olive oil. Their Olio Piro startup had been exporting all of its olive oil to the United States — until new U.S. tariffs moved up their plans to start expanding elsewhere.Vikki Colvinhide caption
body: Body: BusinessThis Tuscan startup sold all its olive oil in the U.S. Then came Trump's tariffsAmericans love olive oil — and import 95% of it. But tariffs are making it harder for Europeans to sell it to Americans.

title: Title: Your call to a local Social Security office may be picked up by someone who can't help
teaser: Teaser: A Social Security Administration office building is seen on March 6 in Nashville, Tenn.George Walker IV/APhide caption
body: Body: PoliticsYour call to a local Social Security office may be picked up by someone who can't helpPhone calls to local Social Security offices are currently being rerouted to other field offices — often to staff who don't have jurisdiction over the caller's case, employees say.

title: Title: River Tiber: Tiny Desk Concert
teaser: Teaser: River Tiber: Tiny Desk Concert
body: Body: River Tiber: Tiny Desk ConcertThe Toronto native takes his turn at the piano, drums, bass and trombone while his bandmates trade instruments and sing along, pushing the barriers of what can happen in this small space.

title: Title: What's the secret to India's moves to conquer the global chess scene?
teaser: Teaser: Seven-year-old Lakshan is coached by Selvabharathy, a trainer at Vishnu Prasanna's Chess Academy in Chennai, India.Viraj Nayarhide caption
body: Body: Goats and SodaWhat's the secret to India's moves to conquer the global chess scene?With the Women's World Cup in the bag and 88 grand masters, India is ready to take over the chess world. And they're making sure their youngsters are poised to checkmate.

title: Title: Dali owners suing ship manufacturer for Baltimore's Key Bridge crash
teaser: Teaser: The container ship Dali is stuck under part of the Francis Scott Key Bridge after the ship hit the bridge Tuesday March 26, 2024, in Baltimore, Md.Steve Helber/APhide caption
body: Body: Dali owners suing ship manufacturer for Baltimore's Key Bridge crashWYPR - 88.1 FM BaltimoreThe owners of the Dali, the ship that hit the Francis Scott Key Bridge in March 2024, are suing the builders of the vessel for defective design.

title: Title: Federal judge halts Arkansas Ten Commandments law
teaser: Teaser: The John Paul Hammerschmidt Federal Building in Fayetteville on July 18, 2025.Antoinette Grajeda/Arkansas Advocatehide caption
body: Body: Federal judge halts Arkansas Ten Commandments lawKUARIn a ruling Monday evening, U.S. District Judge Timothy Brooks blocked the law with a temporary injunction, meaning it cannot go into effect until further court action is taken.

title: Title: Texas Democrats walked out to block the GOP. How well has the tactic worked before?
teaser: Teaser: Texas state lawmakers board a bus following a press conference at the DuPage County Democratic Party headquarters on August 03, 2025 in Carol Stream, Ill. The group of Democratic lawmakers left the state earlier today so a quorum could not be reached during a special session called to redistrict the state.Scott Olson/Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: PoliticsTexas Democrats walked out to block the GOP. How well has the tactic worked before?Dozens of Texas Democrats left the state to protest a redistricting map, facing potentially steep consequences. Lawmaker walkouts have had mixed success in the past — so what is there to gain?

title: Title: Videos of emaciated hostages in Gaza raise pressure on Israel for a ceasefire
teaser: Teaser: Families of hostages protest demanding the release of their loved ones from Hamas captivity in the Gaza Strip at the plaza known as the "hostages square" in Tel Aviv, Israel, Saturday.Ariel Schalit/APhide caption
body: Body: Middle East conflictVideos of emaciated hostages in Gaza raise pressure on Israel for a ceasefireNew images of emaciated Israeli hostages held in Gaza have horrified Israelis and added pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to reach a ceasefire with Hamas.

title: Title: Their son was shot by police in Bangladesh's 2024 protests. They still want justice
teaser: Teaser: Abu Sayed's parents, Mokbul Hussein and Monowara Khatun, sit in the courtyard of their home in Rangpur, Bangladesh, on July 30. On the wall behind them hangs a memorial plaque dedicated to their son who was killed by police during protests last year.Parvez Ahmad Rony for NPRhide caption
body: Body: AsiaTheir son was shot by police in Bangladesh's 2024 protests. They still want justiceIn July and August of 2024 in Bangladesh, student protesters' push for change drove the authoritarian prime minister out of power. Hundreds of demonstrators were killed.

title: Title: Chappell Roan's thick-skinned 'The Subway' captures a survivalist New York mood
teaser: Teaser: On Chappell Roan's new song "The Subway," she captures New York City's unique hardships with a broken heart.Ryan Lee Clemenshide caption
body: Body: ReviewMusicChappell Roan's thick-skinned 'The Subway' captures a survivalist New York moodHer latest single has a new sound (wistful '90s acoustic pop), and a new vibe (toughing out whatever NYC public transportation throws at you, from rats to trash to unexpected encounters with your ex).

title: Title: Big Freedia takes bounce music to church on new album, 'Pressing Onward'

body: Body: Interview highlightsBig Freedia takes bounce music to church on new album, 'Pressing Onward'NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Big Freedia about her new album, "Pressing Onward," and how her childhood singing in the church led her to this moment, fusing gospel with her signature bounce music.

title: Title: An engineer restores pay phones for free public use

body: Body: NationalAn engineer restores pay phones for free public useIn a rural Vermont county, spotty cellphone coverage is the norm. But a local tinkerer is using old technology to help his community stay connected free of charge.

title: Title: Wildfire smoke is like smoking 'half a pack a day.' Here's how to protect yourself
teaser: Teaser: People play rugby in the hazy weather at Brooklyn Bridge Park on July 27, 2025 in New York City. Hazy conditions and a smoke advisory have been caused by smoke as a result of wildfire in Canada.Liao Pan/China News Service/VCG via Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: ClimateWildfire smoke is like smoking 'half a pack a day.' Here's how to protect yourselfAs Canadian wildfires spread smoke across the U.S. the air pollution is dangerous to health. But there are ways to protect yourself. Here's what to know.

title: Title: Why a NASA satellite that scientists and farmers rely on may be destroyed on purpose
teaser: Teaser: A robotic arm attached to the International Space Station brings in the spacecraft carrying one of the two Orbiting Carbon Observatory instruments, known as OCO-3, in 2019. NASA has put out a call for private groups to potentially take over the cost of maintaining the instrument, which measures carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere.NASA TV/NASAhide caption
body: Body: ExclusiveClimateWhy a NASA satellite that scientists and farmers rely on may be destroyed on purposeThe Trump administration has asked NASA staffers to draw up plans to end at least two satellite missions that measure carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, according to current and former NASA employees.

title: Title: Scientists crack the case of the melting sea stars after decade-long hunt
teaser: Teaser: Curator Kylie Lev, left, hands a Pycnopodia helianthoides, known as a sunflower sea star, which was spawned on Feb. 14, 2024, to senior biologist Jess Witherly while being interviewed as part of the California Academy of Sciences' efforts to spawn and raise sunflower sea stars in the eventual goal of reintroducing them to California's coasts, at the Academy on Thursday, June 12, 2025, in San Francisco. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)Jeff Chiu/APhide caption
body: Body: Scientists crack the case of the melting sea stars after decade-long huntKUOWResearchers say they've identified the pathogen behind one of the world's biggest disease outbreaks: a wasting disease that affected billions of sea stars from Alaska to California.

title: Title: Chile's plunging birth rate may foreshadow the future in the U.S.
teaser: Teaser: Macarena Lagos, 18, F. Contreras, 21, and Mariana Sanhueza Weish, 22, are design students at the Catholic University in Santiago. All three voice strong reservations about having children.  Their reasons vary: one doesn't believe she would make a good mother, others want to pursue creative careers, and some feel the world is not a good place to raise children. Santiago, Chile, on Saturday, May. 10, 2025 / Tamara Merino for NPR.Tamara Merino for NPRhide caption
body: Body: WorldChile's plunging birth rate may foreshadow the future in the U.S.Chilean families are having only one child on average. U.S. birthrates are also dropping but it's unclear whether the U.S. will follow into the growing group of "very low" birthrate countries.

title: Title: Leaves piled up after her husband's injury. Then a friend showed up with a rake

body: Body: My Unsung HeroLeaves piled up after her husband's injury. Then a friend showed up with a rakeIn 2017, Eileen Freiberg-Dale's husband, Barney, had a serious bicycle accident that caused a brain injury. Those first few months were among the hardest of her life. A friend offered support.

title: Title: This Tuscan startup sold all its olive oil in the U.S. Then came Trump's tariffs

title: Title: Texas Democrats walked out to block the GOP. How well has the tactic worked before?
teaser: Teaser: Texas state lawmakers board a bus following a press conference at the DuPage County Democratic Party headquarters on August 03, 2025 in Carol Stream, Ill. The group of Democratic lawmakers left the state earlier today so a quorum could not be reached during a special session called to redistrict the state.Scott Olson/Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: PoliticsTexas Democrats walked out to block the GOP. How well has the tactic worked before?Dozens of Texas Democrats left the state to protest a redistricting map, facing potentially steep consequences. Lawmaker walkouts have had mixed success in the past — so what is there to gain?

title: Title: Why a NASA satellite that scientists and farmers rely on may be destroyed on purpose
teaser: Teaser: A robotic arm attached to the International Space Station brings in the spacecraft carrying one of the two Orbiting Carbon Observatory instruments, known as OCO-3, in 2019. NASA has put out a call for private groups to potentially take over the cost of maintaining the instrument, which measures carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere.NASA TV/NASAhide caption
body: Body: ExclusiveClimateWhy a NASA satellite that scientists and farmers rely on may be destroyed on purposeThe Trump administration has asked NASA staffers to draw up plans to end at least two satellite missions that measure carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, according to current and former NASA employees.

title: Title: Scientists crack the case of the melting sea stars after decade-long hunt
teaser: Teaser: Curator Kylie Lev, left, hands a Pycnopodia helianthoides, known as a sunflower sea star, which was spawned on Feb. 14, 2024, to senior biologist Jess Witherly while being interviewed as part of the California Academy of Sciences' efforts to spawn and raise sunflower sea stars in the eventual goal of reintroducing them to California's coasts, at the Academy on Thursday, June 12, 2025, in San Francisco. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)Jeff Chiu/APhide caption
body: Body: Scientists crack the case of the melting sea stars after decade-long huntKUOWResearchers say they've identified the pathogen behind one of the world's biggest disease outbreaks: a wasting disease that affected billions of sea stars from Alaska to California.

(AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)Jeff Chiu/APhide caption

title: Title: Chile's plunging birth rate may foreshadow the future in the U.S.
teaser: Teaser: Macarena Lagos, 18, F. Contreras, 21, and Mariana Sanhueza Weish, 22, are design students at the Catholic University in Santiago. All three voice strong reservations about having children.  Their reasons vary: one doesn't believe she would make a good mother, others want to pursue creative careers, and some feel the world is not a good place to raise children. Santiago, Chile, on Saturday, May. 10, 2025 / Tamara Merino for NPR.Tamara Merino for NPRhide caption
body: Body: WorldChile's plunging birth rate may foreshadow the future in the U.S.Chilean families are having only one child on average. U.S. birthrates are also dropping but it's unclear whether the U.S. will follow into the growing group of "very low" birthrate countries.

body: Body: Life KitTo avoid fakes when shopping online, watch out for these 4 red flagsCounterfeit products, especially medicines and safety gear, can be dangerous. Here's how to spot them on e-commerce platforms like Amazon.

title: Title: Here's back-to-school advice from elementary to high school students
teaser: Teaser: FILE - A student raises their hand in a classroom at Tussahaw Elementary school Aug. 4, 2021, in McDonough, Ga. According to test results released by the Georgia Department of Education on Friday, July 26, 2024, Georgia students in some grades approached pre-pandemic scores in the 2023-2024 school year, while other grades did not. (AP Photo/Brynn Anderson, File)Brynn Anderson/APhide caption
body: Body: Up First NewsletterHere's back-to-school advice from elementary to high school studentsNPR asked elementary to high school students heading back to school to weigh in on what they're doing to prepare for the upcoming school year. They answered the call with advice for their peers.
